[63] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Which CAISO tariff, business practice manual, or governing document defines the ‘Phased Commercial Operation Date (Phased COD)’ construct for interconnections, and what limits does that document specify for maximum MW per phase and the associated security, testing, or milestone obligations? A: Short answer — where it’s defined: CAISO’s Tariff (Appendix A definitions) and the LGIA/GIA implementation plan (Appendix E / the applicable GIA) establish the “phased” / phased‑COD construct; CAISO implements it in its Generator Interconnection / Queue Management BPMs and New Resource Implementation materials (there is a “Phased Commercial Operation Implementation Plan” template). (westerneim.com, caiso.com) Limits and obligations (what the documents say): - There is no single, fixed MW‑per‑phase numeric cap in the Tariff or BPMs — phase size is defined by the GIA/implementation plan (the Interconnection Customer and PTO/CAISO specify the MW for each phase). (westerneim.com, docest.com) - CAISO requires a Phase/Block Implementation Plan, trial‑operation/testing under OP‑5320 (test energy / COM procedures), and market/commercial‑operation (“COM”) rules for partial bidding. Security/milestone rules (site‑exclusivity, deposits, commercial‑viability criteria) and COD time limits (e.g., COD/time‑in‑queue limits and extension criteria) are in the GIDAP/BPMs and GIA annexes. For details see the BPM/GIDAP and OP‑5320 references. (docest.com, caiso.com) If you want, I can pull the exact GIA/BPM clauses and quote the implementation‑plan template language.

[64] Research Agent 🔍 Q: What are ERCOT’s publicly posted Energy Reliability Service (ERS) procurement timelines and registration lead-times (e.g., notice-to-commit windows and required advance registration periods), and what historical ERS clearing or payment rates (e.g., $/MW or $/MWh) are published for 2023–2025? A: Short answer (sources below): - Procurement/registration timelines: ERCOT issues an RFP for each ERS Standard Contract Term (SCT) — there are four SCTs per ERS year (Dec–Mar, Apr–May, Jun–Sep, Oct–Nov). QSEs must submit ERS Resource Identification (ERID) roughly 10 days before Offer submissions; Competitive/Self‑Provision Offers are due ~2–4 weeks before the SCT start; ERCOT notifies awards ~~10 days after offers are due; the ERS Offer Disclosure (offer‑level prices/quantities) is posted 60 days after the SCT start. (ercot.com) - Published clearing/payment rates: ERCOT’s ERS Offer Disclosure (per‑SCT files on ERCOT/MIS) is the authoritative source for $/MW or $/MWh by QSE. Third‑party summaries report 2023 ERS payments ~ $49M and per‑MWh values in roughly $0.29–$53/MWh (see analyses); for 2024–2025, check the ERCOT ERS Offer Disclosure and Procurement Results for each SCT. (ercot.com, lod.io) If you want, I can pull the specific ERS Offer Disclosure files for each SCT in 2023–2025 and extract cleared prices (will fetch and list $/MW or $/MWh by SCT).

[65] Research Agent 🔍 Q: What published regulatory thresholds or permit triggers (for example: annual water withdrawal volumes, cooling‑tower discharge temperature/flow thresholds, or local allocation limits) require an Environmental Impact Report (EIR)/CEQA review, an NPDES permit, or other discretionary water‑supply review for industrial cooling systems sized to serve 150–300 MW facilities in the San Francisco Bay Area (California), Maricopa County/Phoenix (Arizona), and Northern Virginia? A: Short answer (sources below): - California (SF Bay Area): CEQA/EIR is required whenever the lead agency finds a project may have significant impacts; SB 610/10910–10912 requires a Water Supply Assessment for projects meeting statutory thresholds (e.g., >500 dwelling units; industrial plants >1,000 people or >40 acres; or any project whose water demand ≥ a 500‑unit project). Cooling‑water discharges to waters of the U.S. require NPDES and coastal power plants are subject to the State Water Board’s Once‑Through Cooling / thermal rules. (law.justia.com, waterboards.ca.gov) - Arizona (Maricopa County/Phoenix): any discharge to surface waters needs an AZPDES (NPDES) permit (individual or general); groundwater withdrawals in AMAs require ADWR permits for non‑exempt wells (exempt = ≤35 gpm; commercial exempt use ≤10 acre‑feet/yr). (azdeq.gov, azwater.gov) - Northern Virginia: surface‑water withdrawals >10,000 gallons/day are reportable/permit‑reviewable under 9VAC25 (and VPDES/VWP permits are required for discharges/instream impacts). Local water‑supply/allocation rules vary by utility—check the local utility/DEQ. (law.lis.virginia.gov) If you want, I can pull the exact county/city/utility CEQA thresholds and recent NPDES permit examples for specific sites.

[66] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Have any state utility regulators or transmission owners published formal guidance or tariff language that permits contractual curtailment service‑level agreements (curtailment SLAs) or repeated interim curtailments as an approved mechanism to enable provisional energization for large customers, and if so which documents specify allowed terms or limits (for example maximum number or duration of curtailments)? A: Yes. Examples of formal, published language: - California CPUC required IOU RPS pro forma contracts to include economic‑curtailment terms (PG&E: up to 5% of expected annual generation; SCE: negotiated cap ~50–200 hours/year with compensation rules). (CPUC Decision D.11‑04‑030, Apr 2011). (docs.cpuc.ca.gov) - PJM’s OATT/pro forma Interconnection Service Agreements expressly provide for interim/interim Capacity Interconnection Rights (specified MW for an “interim time period” and a termination date). (PJM OATT / ISA provisions). (agreements.pjm.com) - MISO stakeholder/tariff materials describe Provisional/“limited operations” (Provisional GIA / interim operating guide) that set output limits, require protective controls/communications, quarterly output‑limit updates and a termination date tied to network upgrade completion. (misoenergy.org, natlawreview.com) If you want, I can fetch and extract the exact contract/tariff clauses and paragraph citations.

[67] Research Agent 🔍 Q: What factory acceptance test (FAT) and on-site commissioning durations (in days or weeks) do major OEMs or specialty rental providers publicly specify for mobile substations or rental transformers in the ~40–65 MVA class, and which public datasheets, service manuals, or vendor notices cite those durations? (pt.scribd.com) - Meidensha (mobile substation product page): “A mobile substation usually requires a week for installation and commissioning.” (meidensha.com) Notes: many OEM datasheets/service manuals give qualitative statements (days/weeks) rather than fixed schedules; times vary with transformer rating, transport (dry/oil), site testing agreed scope, witness tests, and protections/SCADA commissioning. If you want, I can extract exact quotes/pages/PDF pages and add more OEMs (Hitachi, GE, etc.).

[69] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Do any U.S. utilities or transmission owners publish a standard Temporary Interconnection Agreement (TIA) template, tariff schedule, or explicit temporary/provisional interconnection product that allows interim service blocks (for example ~20–100 MW) while permanent network upgrades proceed, and where are those templates or tariffs publicly posted? (agreements.pjm.com) - MISO: the Generation Interconnection Business Practice Manual (BPM‑015) describes a Provisional Generator Interconnection Agreement (limited/operational output caps while upgrades proceed) and links to the related tariff/whitepapers on MISO’s site. (misoenergy.org, doczz.net) - CAISO and other ISO/RTOs likewise post pro‑forma LGIA/SGIA and tariff appendices (CAISO Tariff Appendices BB/FF/EE etc.) on their public tariff/agreements pages. (caiso.com) If you want, I can fetch the exact pro‑forma files (Interim ISA, BPM‑015 excerpt, or CAISO LGIA/SGIA) and provide direct links.

[70] Research Agent 🔍 Q: What are the publicly posted permit-processing timelines, route restrictions, and typical scheduling lead-times (in weeks) for heavy‑haul transport and special‑crane lifts for oversized power transformers in California (state DOTs/ports), Texas (TxDOT/ports), Arizona (ADOT/Maricopa County), and Virginia (VDOT/ports), as published by the relevant agencies? A: Summary (typical, per each agency’s public rules): - California (Caltrans): standard single‑trip permits may be issued days in advance; repetitive permits request a minimum 14 business‑day processing; variance/special‑processing (very large/heavy) should be submitted ~30 days ahead; written route/structure surveys required for extreme heights. (dot.ca.gov) - Texas (TxDMV/TxDOT): routine permits often 24–72 hrs; “superheavy/superload” applications require detailed route/engineering and are requested 6–8 weeks (or longer) before movement; route inspections/curfews apply. (txdmv.gov) - Arizona (ADOT / Maricopa County): Class C (special) permits average ~48 hours issuance (engineering reviews up to ~2 weeks if bridge analysis required); Maricopa County plan reviews target ~20 business days for ROW permits; local city reviews may require 2–5 business days. (azdot.gov, maricopa.gov) - Virginia (VDOT/localities/ports): superloads require engineering review and are to be submitted ~10 business days (localities process standard permits by next business day; nonstandard up to 10 business days); terminals schedule project/heavy‑lift with terminal/stevedore (lead‑times vary). (law.lis.virginia.gov, operations.portofvirginia.com) If you want, I can pull the specific permit pages/terminal heavy‑lift contacts for particular ports or transformer dimensions.

(global.abb, new.abb.com) Other large rental vendors (Aggreko, GE/GE Vernova, major rental houses) publish rental terms, T&Cs or product brochures on their sites (not typically public “slot calendars” or MOU templates). If you want, I can pull direct URLs or search for a specific provider’s reservation/agreement PDF.

[90] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Have any state public utility commissions, ISOs, or transmission owners approved tariff provisions, regulatory orders, or contract templates that permit customer‑escrowed staged Transmission Service Agreement (TSA) payments or escrowed funds to be used to finance earlier procurement of temporary capacity or to accelerate transmission owner procurement; if so, where are those provisions or decisions publicly posted? [91] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Which public permits, agency decisions, or permit conditions for temporary or emergency generator fleets include enforceable requirements for real‑time public emissions or noise dashboards, and do any of those documents report measurable outcomes (for example permit timeline reductions or litigation avoidance) attributed to those transparency conditions? (ww2.arb.ca.gov, epa.gov) If you want, I can (a) search specific state/air‑district permit dockets (e.g., MN, CA, TX, NY) for any recent exceptions, or (b) pull sample permit language (PERP, Title V, local permits) that shows what transparency/reporting is actually required.

[92] Research Agent 🔍 Q: List publicly available PUC, FERC, or ISO filings and orders where network/transmission upgrades triggered by a specific large customer interconnection were reclassified as regionally recoverable (socialized) rather than participant‑funded; provide the case numbers, decision documents, and the dollar amounts reclassified where documented. A: Here are three well‑documented examples (case, decision document, documented reclassified amounts where available): - Duke Energy Hinds, LLC v. Entergy Services, Inc., 102 FERC ¶ 61,068 (Jan. 28, 2003) — FERC ordered reclassification of certain interconnection‑constructed facilities as Network Upgrades (modifying IAs so costs become broadly recoverable); the FERC order: 102 FERC ¶ 61,068. (Decision text — FERC/Federal Register). (govinfo.gov) Amount: the order directs reclassification/crediting but does not specify a single dollar figure in the decision. (projectfinance.law) - Tenaska Clear Creek Wind, LLC v. Southwest Power Pool, Inc., Docket EL21‑77‑000 — Order Granting in Part and Denying in Part Complaint, 177 FERC ¶ 61,200 (Dec. 16, 2021). FERC found SPP had in effect assigned roughly $66 million in affected‑system network upgrade costs to Tenaska during restudies and required restudy/compliance. (FERC case page and orders). (ferc.gov, casetext.com) Amount documented: ~ $66 million (restudy assignments; compliance restudy later reported ~$88M assigned in 2022 filings). (casetext.com) - Jeffers South, LLC (MISO) — FERC reversed an ALJ finding that had required the merchant developer to pay for a new 161 kV line (~$43 million) as a project‑specific assignment; FERC’s order curtailed assigning that full upgrade to the interconnection customer. (summary reporting and FERC orders on the Jeffers South proceedings). (foley.com) Amount documented: ≈ $43 million in transmission line costs at issue. (foley.com) This is not an exhaustive list; many similar FERC/ISO orders (and related state PUC dockets) exist. If you want, I can (a) pull the exact FERC eLibrary docket links/PDFs for each order (and quote the precise paragraphs that reclassify cost responsibility), or (b) expand the list to other regions (PJM, CAISO, ISO‑NE, MISO) with docket numbers and dollar amounts.

[93] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Which regulatory or utility documents (orders, tariff filings, or interconnection study reports) record approvals of temporary or conditional ATC allocations or interim interconnection service that are explicitly tied to enforceable local permit conditions (for example run‑hour caps, continuous emissions monitoring), and what numeric limits or monitoring obligations were specified in those documents? (law.cornell.edu, govinfo.gov) 3) Transmission/interconnection templates & manuals that record “interim” interconnection rights but rely on local permit conditions to set numeric limits — e.g., PJM’s Interim Interconnection Service Agreement / Temporary Energy Resource rules and PJM Manual 15 (which treats regulatory run‑hour caps as the basis for Energy Market Opportunity Cost). If you want, I can pull specific interconnection ISAs or ATC permits for named projects/ISOs.

[94] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Which transmission owners or utilities publish acceptance criteria or guidance stating that factory‑witnessed relay/FAT reports and submitted automated protection‑setting scripts may be accepted in lieu of full on‑site witness testing to shorten on‑site commissioning, and where are those acceptance criteria or test‑witnessing policies documented? (paperzz.com) If you want, I can pull the specific clause language for a given TO (e.g., NYISO/PJM/NE/CAISO/your local TO).

[95] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Are there publicly available regulatory orders, ISO tariff filings, or utility decisions that document use of contracted market commitments (for example ERS/DR contracts, leased rental generation or BESS) as an approved basis to permit provisional energization or provisional firming of large loads while permanent network upgrades are pending; if so, cite the documents and the MW amounts approved? A: Short answer: Yes — there are public tariff orders and regulatory decisions showing contracted market commitments (ERS/DR, leased gens, BESS or RA contracts) being accepted as mechanisms to bridge capacity/deliverability shortfalls or to permit provisional/interim service while network upgrades proceed. Key public examples: - PJM tariff / Interim/Provisional Interconnection Service (Interim ISA / Provisional Interconnection Service language) — allows provisional interconnection/injection and negotiated MW quantities on a case‑by‑case basis via Interim ISAs (no single universal MW cap; set in each agreement). (agreements.pjm.com) - ERCOT Market Notice / winter 2023–24 RFP — ERCOT procured up to 3,000 MW of generation and demand‑response (ERS/DR) as a short‑term reliability bridge. (Procurement documents/market notice describe the 3,000 MW target and contract terms.) (ercot.com) - California CPUC summer‑reliability decisions — D.21‑02‑028 and D.21‑03‑056 directed IOUs to procure incremental capacity (including storage, imports, at‑risk generation, DR) to meet reliability; D.21‑03‑056 specified IOUs collectively procure at least ~1.0–1.5 GW (month‑ahead seasonal procurement) and later CPUC orders expanded procurement programs. These orders have been used by utilities to justify contracting BESS/RA to bridge deliverability while upgrades proceed. (cpuc.ca.gov, powermag.com) Note: many approvals are fact‑specific (tariff or ISA language, utility advice letters, or commission resolutions) so MW amounts are either program targets (ERCOT/CPUC) or negotiated per‑project (PJM Interim ISAs). If you want, I can pull specific Interim ISA examples or utility advice letters showing an awarded MW amount for a named project.

[96] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Which utilities’ interconnection standards, transmission owner design manuals, or engineering construction standards explicitly require a single large power transformer installation (for example one 345/500 kV LPT) at customer POIs instead of allowing multiple smaller parallel transformers, and which specific sections or clauses define acceptable transformer configurations? A: Short answer: There is no single industry‑wide list — most Transmission Owners handle transformer count case‑by‑case. Example specifics found in public TO/IA documents: - FirstEnergy’s “Requirements for Transmission‑Connected Facilities” requires new generator facilities be isolated by a power transformer and specifies acceptable winding connections; PJM queue studies referencing that document repeatedly require a single generator‑lead breaker (i.e., you may not use individual GSU breakers to protect the generator lead). See FE Req’ts §14.2.6 and the “single breaker” language in multiple PJM study reports. (scribd.com, pjm.com) - PJM’s Transmission Owner Guidelines and individual TO design manuals (e.g., PJM TO “Large Power Transformers” and specific TO interconnection requirements / LGIAs) define acceptable GSU winding, BIL and protection arrangements but leave transformer count/configuration to the TO or the executed IA/Facilities Study (project Appendix A often shows a single GSU for that project). These are TO‑specific, not a universal prohibition on parallel smaller transformers. (pjm.com, nyisoviewer.etariff.biz) If you want, I can search specific TO manuals (e.g., AEP, PSEG, NYPA, SCE) and extract the exact clauses for each.

[118] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Which transmission owners or utilities have publicly published engineering guidance or interconnection criteria stating that an aggregated commercial ‘firmness bundle’ (bundled contracted DR, leased BESS, and mobile GTs under enforceable SLAs) may be treated as an equivalent mitigation to an N‑1 network contingency for provisional energization or interconnection study purposes? (cpuc.ca.gov) - ComEd / Exelon transmission guidance — published interconnection guidelines require continuous telemetry and witnessed testing for larger connections (instant MW/MVAR, cumulative MWh, unit & breaker status, terminal volts) and describe how contractual/operational measures are evaluated in studies. (docslib.org, scribd.com) If you want, I can (1) pull the SCE/SDG&E/PG&E OpFlex pilot reports and quote the specific telemetry/acceptance tests they used, or (2) search other TOs (PJM TOs, NYTOs, MISO TOs) for similar explicit language.

[119] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Which U.S. transmission owners or utilities have publicly posted standardized Point‑of‑Interconnection (POI) design packages (single‑line diagrams, protection/relay‑setting templates, SCADA/telemetry specs) that explicitly pre‑approve modular POI configurations allowing parallel deployment of multiple mobile/pad transformer units (for example 2–4 units of ~40–65 MVA)? Provide the document names/URLs and any stated numeric limits (number of units, MVA per unit, or total MW). A: Short answer: I found several U.S. transmission owners that publish standardized POI / interconnection design packages or “station guide” templates (examples below), but I could not find any publicly-posted POI design package that explicitly and numerically “pre‑approves” modular POI configurations (e.g., “2–4 x 40–65 MVA”) in the public documents I reviewed. Examples of public POI/TO design packages I checked: - NYSEG / RG&E — transmission / interconnection information and station/POI guidance. (nyseg.com) - PJM — “Specific Transmission Owner Guidelines” (TO technical/design standards repository). (pjm.com) - PG&E — Greenbook / Wholesale Distribution Tariff design manuals (standard single‑line/relay templates). (fr.scribd.com) What I did NOT find publicly (based on the above searches): an explicit numeric pre‑approval statement (number of units, MVA per unit or total MW) in those standard POI packages. If you’d like, I can (a) search the TOs you care about individually (e.g., AEP, Dominion, SCE, Entergy, Xcel) for any internal “prefab / modular POI” specs, or (b.1) pull specific excerpts from the three documents above showing the templates I reviewed.

[120] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Which utilities, transmission owners, or vendors publish standard scheduling lead‑times (in days or weeks) for utility‑witnessed factory acceptance tests (FATs), on‑site commissioning witness slots, and formal protection/relay acceptance windows required prior to energization, and where are those published scheduling rules or calendars available? A: Short answer — many U.S. RTOs/TOs and major vendors publish scheduling lead‑times and witness/commissioning rules; examples and where to find them: - NYISO / Connecting Transmission Owners — lead‑times in SGIA/OATT and interconnection templates (e.g., 5 business‑day notice for on‑site verification; 10 business‑day window for TO inspection). (nyisoviewer.etariff.biz) - ERCOT — Planning Guide / interconnection guides publish study/implementation and commissioning windows (commissioning/final‑testing milestones shown in planning guides). (ercot.com) - Manufacturers/vendors — Siemens, ABB, GE publish FAT/SAT service descriptions and FAT witness options; procurement/contract clauses commonly require 2–8 weeks’ notice (vendor FAT pages and sample contract clauses). (siemens.com, manuals.plus) Also check each TO’s “Transmission Owner Technical Requirements” / interconnection procedures on RTO or utility websites (PJM, MISO, CAISO, AEP, Duke, ITC etc.) for their specific calendars and booking rules.

[121] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Which transformer, mobile‑substation, gas‑turbine, or BESS rental OEMs or brokers publicly offer refundable option‑deposit or escrow reservation mechanisms for reserving delivery slots for mobile LPTs, mobile substations, rental GTs, or rental BESS, and what vendor‑published deposit amounts, cancellation terms, and guaranteed delivery/window commitments (in calendar months) are stated in those public documents? A: Short answer: Public, vendor‑published reservation/option‑deposit provisions in the power‑equipment rental sector are rare. I found: - Siemens — a 2008 Siemens Power “Reservation Agreement” with Idaho Power requiring a $2,750,000 reservation fee that the contract labels non‑refundable and which tied delivery to “Guaranteed Delivery Dates” / a 90‑day reservation period. (sec.gov) - Aggreko — markets mobile substations and posts standard T&Cs (delivery/rental clauses) but I found no public refundable option‑deposit / escrow reservation mechanism in their published materials. (aggreko.com) - Examples of refundable escrow reservation language exist in other sectors/brokers (e.g., MVP.Aero’s deposit/escrow clause: refundable less a $500 non‑refundable portion). These are analogous models but not from major transformer/GT/BESS OEMs. (expydoc.com) I could not locate publicly posted OEM/broker contracts for mobile LPTs/mobile substations/rental GTs/rental BESS that advertise refundable option‑deposit or escrow reservation amounts, cancellation schedules, and calendar‑month delivery windows. This may exist in confidential/quote‑level contracts — I can run targeted vendor searches or contact specific OEMs/brokers if you want.

[122] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Which publicly available permit conditions, agency orders, or permit decision documents require operators of temporary or mobile generator fleets to publish near‑real‑time aggregated emissions or noise dashboards and to meet specified complaint‑response SLAs (for example 48‑hour response), and where are those permit conditions posted? A: Short answer: there is no single, widely‑used permit template that universally forces temporary/mobile generator fleets to run public near‑real‑time emissions/noise dashboards plus a fixed complaint‑response SLA (e.g., “48 hours”). Where agencies have imposed such public‑reporting or fast complaint‑response requirements they are case‑specific — contained in local air‑district or state permit decisions, emergency orders, or enforcement settlements — and are posted on the issuing agency’s permit/notice portal. Where to look (examples): - CARB’s Portable Equipment Registration Program (PERP) — registration/notification rules and the PERP data system on CARB’s site (search PERP DMS and local district PERP pages). (ww2.arb.ca.gov, perpdms.arb.ca.gov) - EPA power‑sector CEMS/AMPD shows how federal permitting can require near‑real‑time hourly CEMS reporting for large units (public dashboards), but that is for stationary large sources, not generic mobile fleets. (epa.gov) - Individual permit examples (posted on state/district permit portals) show varied reporting timetables (e.g., DC permit language requiring written report of non‑compliance within three working days). Search the relevant state/air‑district “permit” or “public notice” pages for specific fleet permits/orders. (docest.com) If you want, tell me the jurisdiction(s) or fleet/operator names you care about and I’ll pull the exact permit/order text and links.

[123] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Which major transformer OEMs publish standard ‘catalog’ specifications for large power transformers (examples: standard HV bushing types, common on‑load tap‑changer models) and also publish any advertised expedited‑build or option‑slot lead‑time commitments that quantify calendar‑time reductions (in months) versus fully bespoke designs? Provide the public datasheets, technical notes, or press releases that state those specifications and lead‑time figures. A: Short answer — two OEMs with public catalog specs + explicit, quantified “fast/standard” lead‑time claims are: - Hitachi Energy — publishes component/catalog specs (Compas bushing & OLTC selector) and a public delivery‑times page listing standard lead times in weeks for bushings and tap‑changers (i.e., concrete calendar figures). (compasproductselector.hitachienergy.com, hitachienergy.com) - GE Vernova / Prolec GE — publishes power‑transformer product brochures/catalogs and product pages that advertise quantified fast‑delivery figures for certain standard products (e.g., SUPERBUTE instrument transformers: “standard lead times of 4–6 weeks, nearly half the industry average”; GE “packaged solutions” cite 6–8 week turnaround for pre‑designed modules). (gevernova.com) Notes: Siemens Energy, Hyosung, Hyundai, Mitsubishi, etc., publish detailed component and transformer datasheets/catalogs (bushing types, OLTC models), but I did not find clear public pages that state an advertised expedited‑build option explicitly quantified in calendar months vs a fully bespoke unit; if you want, I can run targeted searches or pull PDFs for any specific OEM or product line.

[124] Research Agent 🔍 Q: What published port, state DOT, or heavy‑haul booking/reservation policies exist in California, Texas (TxDOT/major ports), Arizona (ADOT/Maricopa County), and Virginia (VDOT/ports) that specify required advance reservation lead‑times, typical berth/crane booking windows, route pre‑clearance timelines, or cancellation/penalty terms for arrival and mobilization of oversized transformer shipments; provide the agency documents or guidance and the typical lead‑time ranges (in weeks) stated. A: Summary (documents + typical lead‑time ranges): - California — Caltrans Transportation Permits (Single‑Trip / Single‑Trip I; route development may add time). Single‑trip permits are valid 7 days and “may be issued up to 3 days in advance”; complex Single‑Trip I/route development require additional processing (days–weeks). (dot.ca.gov) - Texas — TxDMV / TxPROS (Superheavy single‑trip): applicants told to submit applications “six to eight weeks” before required date (unless pre‑approved route exists). (≈6–8 weeks). (txdmv.gov) - Arizona — ADOT oversize/Class C guidance: standard permits often same‑day to a few days, but complex Class C/superloads require route/coordination; Maricopa County ROW plan review targets ~20 business days (≈3–4 weeks). (range: days–4 weeks for county review; larger superloads longer). (azdot.gov, maricopa.gov) - Virginia — DMV/VDOT hauling (Superload) regs: superload requests “should be submitted … at least 10 working days” (≈2 weeks); DMV guidance also notes 2–3 business‑day minimum for scheduling/rescheduling some superloads. (law.lis.virginia.gov, transactions.dmv.virginia.gov) If you want, I can collect specific port/terminal project‑cargo booking rules (LA/LB, Oakland, Houston, Port of Virginia) and crane/berth‑booking windows (many terminals use “as‑far‑in‑advance‑as‑possible” or terminal‑specific appointment windows such as 48‑hour container appointment rules).
